title: Linear Combinations

lemmas.name: LinearAlgebraGame.neg_one_smul_v
lemmas.altTitle: {K V} (fk : Field K) (acg : AddCommGroup V) (vs : LinearAlgebraGame.VectorSpace K V) (v : V) : -1 • v = -v

lemmas.name: LinearAlgebraGame.smul_zero_v
lemmas.altTitle: {K V} (fk : Field K) (acg : AddCommGroup V) (vs : LinearAlgebraGame.VectorSpace K V) (a : K) : a • 0 = 0

lemmas.altTitle:
{K V} (fk : Field K) (acg : AddCommGroup V) (vs : LinearAlgebraGame.VectorSpace K V) {W}
  (hW : LinearAlgebraGame.isSubspace W) : 0 ∈ W

lemmas.altTitle:
{K V} (fk : Field K) (acg : AddCommGroup V) (vs : LinearAlgebraGame.VectorSpace K V) {W}

lemmas.name: LinearAlgebraGame.zero_smul_v
lemmas.altTitle: {K V} (fk : Field K) (acg : AddCommGroup V) (vs : LinearAlgebraGame.VectorSpace K V) (w : V) : 0 • w = 0

lemmas.name: MulAction.mul_smul
lemmas.altTitle: {α} {β} [Monoid α] [MulAction α β] (x y : α) (b : β) : (x * y) • b = x • y • b

lemmas.name: Nat.add_succ
lemmas.altTitle: (n m : ℕ) : n + Nat.succ m = Nat.succ (n + m)

lemmas.name: add_right_cancel
lemmas.altTitle: {G} [Add G] [IsRightCancelAdd G] {a b c} (a✝ : a + b = c + b) : a = c

lemmas.name: add_smul
lemmas.altTitle: {R} {M} [Semiring R] [AddCommMonoid M] [Module R M] (r s : R) (x : M) : (r + s) • x = r • x + s • x

lemmas.name: le_iff_exists_add
lemmas.altTitle: {α} [CanonicallyOrderedAddCommMonoid α] {a b} : a ≤ b ↔ ∃ c, b = a + c

lemmas.name: one_smul
lemmas.altTitle: (M : Type u_1) {α} [Monoid M] [MulAction M α] (b : α) : 1 • b = b

lemmas.name: smul_add
lemmas.altTitle: {M} {A} [AddZeroClass A] [DistribSMul M A] (a : M) (b₁ b₂ : A) : a • (b₁ + b₂) = a • b₁ + a • b₂

lemmas.name: symm
lemmas.altTitle: {α} {r} [IsSymm α r] {a b} (a✝ : r a b) : r b a

introduction:
The first level of this world will introduce the definition of a linear combination. Let's
say we want to express that some vector `x` is a linear combination of some set `S ⊆ V`. This means
that there is some number of elements in `S`, that after some scalar multiplication, sums to `x`. We can
call this set of elements summing to `x` `s`, where `s : Finset V`, and `↑s ⊆ S`. We are using Finset
here, which means that `s` is a finite subset of V. This is because we can only sum in a way that makes
sense over a finite set. If `s` was infinite, there could be multiple ways of summing it to get different
answers., or a sum might not even exist. We also need to multiply every element of `s` by a scalar before
summing, whether that scalar be `1`, `0`, or anything else. We can represent this by a function `f : V → K`,
where each element of `s` gets mapped to the scalar we multiply by. Now, we are able to understand the
definition of linear combinations:

'''
def is_linear_combination (S : Set V) (x : V) : Prop :=
  ∃ (s : Finset V) (f : V → K), (↑s ⊆ S) ∧ (x = Finset.sum s (fun v => f v • v))
'''
descrFormat: example (h : x = 2) (g: y = 4) : x + x = y  := by
conclusion: This last message appears if the level is solved.
